case_name: Northern Railway Co-operative Credit Society Ltd., Jodhpur v. Kanraj Mehta, A. C. Sharma, V. D. Sharma and G. S. Saxena

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated October 7 1963 of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan Jaipur in Case No. 2 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated October 7 1963 of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan Jaipur in Case No. 2 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellant is the Northern Railway Co-operative Credit Society Ltd., Jodhpur registered in 1920 under the Co-operative Societies Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in this appeal, brought up by special leave, is the Northern Railway Co-operative Credit Society Ltd., Jodhpur  hereinafter referred to as the Society  which is an Association of the employees of the Northern Railway at Jodhpur registered in 1920 under the Co- operative Societies Act.

facts.text: Society had in its employment 10 or 11 persons including Kamraj Mehta Head Clerk, Madho Lal Accountant, and three other Clerks A. C. Sharma, V. D. Sharma and G. S Saxena.

anchor.surface_text: The Society had in its employment 10 or 11 persons including Kamraj Mehta, the Head Clerk, Madho Lal, the Accountant, and three other Clerks, A. C. Sharma, V. D. Sharma and G. S Saxena.

facts.text: At a meeting of the Committee of Management held on 6th April 1956 decided to hold 36th and 37th Annual General Meeting on 28th April 1956 for years 1953-54 and 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: At a meeting of the Committee of Management held on 6th April, 1956, it was decided to hold the 36th and 37th Annual General Meeting of the Shareholders for the years 1953-54 and 1954-55 on 28th April, 1956, i.e., after a period of about 22 days.

facts.text: Kanraj Mehta applied for leave on 8th April 1956 on medical grounds with certificate from registered Vaid extended up to 2nd May 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, Kanraj Mehta, the Head Clerk, on 8th April, 1956, applied for leave on medical grounds, having submitted a certificate from a registered Vaid. Initially, the application for leave was for four days,. but, by subsequent applications, he companytinued to extend his leave up to 2nd May, 1956.

facts.text: Other four Clerks A. C. Sharma, V. D. Sharma, G. S Saxena put applications between 12th and 15th April 1956 on similar Medical Certificates continued leave up to 30th April to 4th May 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The other. four Clerks, mentioned above, also, put in applications between 12th and 15th April, 1956 on similar Medical Certificates and companytinued their leave up to dates falling between 30th April and 4th May, 1956.

facts.text: Society decided to take disciplinary action against Kanraj Mehta, A. C. Sharma, V. D. Sharma and G. S. Saxena alleging conspiracy to paralyse working by collective sick certificates.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial dispute decided by the award, against which the present appeal is directed, related to four of these Clerks- Kanraj Mehta, A. C. Sharma, V. D. Sharma and G. S. Saxena, against -whom the Society decided to take disciplinary action, The case of the Society was that these persons had companyspired to paralyse the working of the Society at of the impending Annual,General Meeting on 28th April, 1956, by companylectively submitting sickness certificates.

facts.text: Society issued letter to Kanraj Mehta directing to attend Railway Dispensary on 20th April 1956 for medical examination by Dr. I B. P. Mathur.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Kanraj Mehta, the Society issued a letter in response to his application for leave directing him to attend the Railway Dispensary, at 7.45 hrs. on 20th April, 1956 and asking him to report to Dr. I B. P. Mathur for medical examination.

facts.text: Kanraj Mehta did not comply with direction to attend medical examination and continued to send leave applications with Vaid certificates.

anchor.surface_text: Kanraj did number companyply with this direction and companytinued to send further applications for leave accompanied by the certificates ofthe Vaid.

facts.text: Kanraj Mehta allowed to resume duty on 3rd May 1956 after expiry of leave asked.

anchor.surface_text: His leave applications were never actually sanctioned, but he was allowed to resume duty after the expiry -of the leave asked for by him in his last application, i.e on 3rd May, 1956.

facts.text: Society issued charge-sheet against Kanraj Mehta on 19th May 1956 containing five charges.

anchor.surface_text: Then on the 19th. day, 1956, the Society issued a - charge-sheet against Kanrai Mehta companytaining five charges which .are reproduced below

facts.text: Kanraj Mehta sent reply to charge-sheet on 25th May 1956 denying charges as vague and requesting representation by Railway or Union official.

anchor.surface_text: On, 25th May, 1956,. Kanraj sent his reply to the charge- sheet. In that reply, he took the plea that here were numberdisciplinary framed and issued for the employees of the Society...

facts.text: Committee of Enquiry appointed consisting of Shri Deodutta Gaur Chairman, Bhailal and Vishvadeo Purohit members, informed to Kanraj by letter dated 28th June 1956.

anchor.surface_text: A Committee of Enquiry was appointed, companysisting of Shri Deodutta Gaur as Chairman, and Bhailal and Vishvadeo Purohit as members to enquire into the charges against Kanraj. The information of the companystitution of this Committee was companyveyed to Kanraj by the letter dated 28th June 1956...

facts.text: Kanraj insisted on being accompanied by Railway employee or Union official at enquiry, request not acceded, refused to appear.

anchor.surface_text: and he was also told that he would be allowed to be accompanied by any employee of the Society at the enquiry if he so desired, but number by any other person as requested by him. Kanraj, however companytinued to insist...

facts.text: Enquiry Committee submitted report on 4th August 1956 finding charges proved based on record.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee then submitted its report on 4th August, 1956. In the report, the Committee first companysidered the questions. whether it should proceed to record evidence...

facts.text: Vice-Chairman issued fresh notice to Kanraj on 5th September 1956 provisional decision to dismiss.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on 5th September, 1956, the Vice-Chairman issued a fresh numberice to Kanraj, stating that he had companye to the provisional decision that Kanraj should be dismissed from service...

facts.text: Kanraj requested copy of proceedings and findings on 13th September 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, Kanraj, on 13th September, 1956, sent a letter requesting the Vice-Chairman to supply to him a full ,copy of the proceedings and findings of the Enquiry Committee...

facts.text: Kanraj sent further reply on 16th September 1956 pleading not guilty.

anchor.surface_text: Kanraj, on 16th September, 1956, sent a further letter in reply to this letter sent by the Hony. Secretary. In this letter, he made a grievance...

facts.text: Kanraj removed from service with effect from 17th September 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On 17th September, 1956, a letter was then issued under the signature of the Honorary Secretary informing Kanraj that he had been removed from service with elect from the 17th September, 1956...

facts.text: Government of Rajasthan made reference to Industrial Tribunal Rajasthan Jaipur under s.10(1)(d) Industrial Disputes Act on request of Uttariya Railway Mazdoor Union.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the dispute relating to the removal of Kanraj and the award of punishment to the other three employees. was taken up by the Uttariya Railway Mazdoor Union, Jodhpur, and at the request sent through the Secretary of that Union a reference was made by the Government of Rajasthan...

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held charges vague and Kanraj entitled to copies of reports, set aside removal order, restored to position on 13th September 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal discussed in detail the case of Kanraj and held that the demand of Kanraj to be allowed to take assistance from a stranger to the Society was unjustified... The Tribunal also accepted the plea of Kanraj that the charges which had been framed against Kanraj were rather vague...

facts.text: Society filed petition under Art.226 in Rajasthan High Court for writ of prohibition, dismissed on 7th February 1962 holding reference competent.

anchor.surface_text: while the reference was pending before the Industrial Tribunal, the Society filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan at Jodhpur... A Division Bench of the High Court, by its judgment dated 7th February, 1962, dismissed the petition...

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court judgment final and binding, plea of incompetent reference fails.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant having failed to do so, the, judgment of the High Court became final, and, companysequently, binding between the parties.

facts.text: Subsequent to Tribunal order, Kanraj reinstated and Society took fresh proceedings for dismissal, now subject to another dispute.

anchor.surface_text: We were, however, informed by learned companynsel for the appellant that, subsequent to the order of the Tribunal, Kanraj was actually reinstated and fresh proceedings for his dismissal were taken by the Society against him.
Appeal by special leave from the award dated October 7 1963 of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan Jaipur in Case No. 2 of 1959.

The appellant in this appeal, brought up by special leave, is the Northern Railway Co-operative Credit Society Ltd., Jodhpur  hereinafter referred to as the Society  which is an Association of the employees of the Northern Railway at Jodhpur registered in 1920 under the Co- operative Societies Act.

issues.text: Whether the reference to the Industrial Tribunal was incompetent because the dispute was an individual dispute of four employees and was not an industrial dispute as it was not taken up by the workmen of the Society

anchor.surface_text: The first point urged was that, in this case, the reference to the Industrial Tribunal was incompetent, because the dispute referred to the Tribunal was an individual dispute of four employees and was not an industrial dispute as it was not taken up by the workmen of the Society.

issues.text: Whether the plea seeking to raise the incompetence of the reference was barred by the principle of res judicata on account of the High Court's judgment dismissing the Art. 226 petition

anchor.surface_text: When this point was raised on behalf of the appellant, a preliminary objection was taken by learned counsel appearing for the respondents that this plea sought to be raised on behalf  if the appellant was barred by the principle of res judicata.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal was wrong in setting aside the order of removal of Kanraj on the ground that the Vice-Chairman refused to supply copies of the Enquiry Committee reports and whether a second show cause notice was required under principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution did not apply, because Kanraj was not a public servant, and the principles of natural justice did- not require that a second show cause notice must be given by every employer

issues.text: Whether the respondents could support the Tribunal's order on grounds decided against them or not urged before the Tribunal, analogous to O. XLI r. 22 CPC

anchor.surface_text: Reliance for this proposition was placed on a decision of this Court in Rambhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji and Others.  1  In that case, an appeal was brought to this Court against the judgment of an Election Tribunal, and one of the respondents wanted to support the order of the Tribunal on grounds which had been negatived by the Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether the charges framed against Kanraj were vague and whether that violated principles of natural justice by denying adequate opportunity to meet the charges

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this case, as enumerated by us above, show that the charge-sheet which was served on Kanraj was in fact very vague and did number companytain any such details as companyld enable him to give any explanation.

D. Sharma and G. Saxena. was illegal or unjustified

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court dismissing the Art. 226 petition holding the reference competent became final and binding as no appeal was filed under Art. 133 or 136, barring the plea of incompetent reference by res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, it is clear that if the appellant wanted to challenge the correctness of the decision of the High Court holding that this dispute was an industrial dispute, the appropriate remedy was to come up in appeal against the judgment of the High Court either by a certificate under Art. 133 or by -special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The appellant having failed to do so, the, judgment of the High Court became final, and, consequently, binding between the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court order in independent Art. 226 proceeding was final, not interlocutory; distinguished Satyadhyan Ghosal; applied Ramesh v. Gendalal on finality; no appeal taken.

holdings.text: The plea of incompetent reference is not open in this appeal; first point fails.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal brought up against the award of the Tribunal, consequently, it is no longer open to the appellant to raise the plea which was rejected by the High Court by its judgment dated 7th February, 1962. The first point raised on behalf of the appellant, therefore, fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct conclusion from binding High Court judgment.

holdings.text: Respondents entitled to support Tribunal's order on grounds negatived by Tribunal or not urged but patent on record.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance for this proposition was placed on a decision of this Court in Rambhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji and Others.  1  In that case, an appeal was brought to this Court against the judgment of an Election Tribunal, and one of the respondents wanted to support the order of the Tribunal on grounds which had been negatived by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to O. XLI r.22 CPC; follows Rambhai Patel and Powari Tea Estate; considerations of justice permit; court power to decide all points.

holdings.text: Charge-sheet served on Kanraj was very vague, lacking details to enable explanation, violating principles of natural justice by denying adequate opportunity.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of each charge shows vagueness; no rules enforcing medical exam order; material not disclosed; Kanraj justified in complaining.

holdings.text: Kanraj not entitled to representation by stranger to Society at enquiry; Tribunal correctly held demand unjustified.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal discussed in detail the case of Kanraj and held that the demand of Kanraj to be allowed to take assistance from a stranger to the Society was unjustified... It is true that the Tribunal correctly held that Kanraj was not entitled to be represented by a stranger to the Society at the enquiry proposed to be held against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Tribunal; Kanraj's insistence unreasonable, condemned.

holdings.text: Principles of natural justice did not generally require second show cause notice, but here necessary due to prior vagueness and non-disclosure; Tribunal justified in setting aside removal order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.311 inapplicable; general rule no second notice, but exception where prior enquiry defective (vague charges, no material disclosure, no opportunity); second notice only chance to cure.

holdings.text: Not appropriate to interfere with Tribunal's reinstatement direction given subsequent reinstatement and fresh proceedings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Might have force per Assam Oil, but moot due to events post-Tribunal order; avoids complications.

precedents.citation: Satyadhyan Ghosal and Others v. Sm. Deorajin Debi and Another.  1

anchor.surface_text: Satyadhyan Ghosal and Others v. Sm. Deorajin Debi and Another.  1  In that case, a question had arisen about the applicability of s. 28 of the Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act, 1949. The plea relating to it was rejected by the Munsif trying the suit.

precedents.cited_proposition: it is not necessary that an interlocutory order must be challenged immediately by an appeal and can be challenged when an appeal is filed against the final order in a civil proceeding
precedents.cited_holding: the order of the High Court, holding that s. 28 of the Act was applicable, could not operate as res judicata in the appeal before this Court, because the High Courts order of remand was merely an interlocutory order

precedents.citation: Ramesh and Another v. Gendalal Motilal Patni and Others 2

anchor.surface_text: Ramesh and Another v. Gendalal Motilal Patni and Others 2  that when exercising jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution, the High Court does not hear an appeal or revision. The High Court is moved to intervene and to bring before itself the record of a case decided by or pending before a Court or Tribunal or any authority within the High Courts jurisdiction.

precedents.cited_proposition: when exercising jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution, the High Court does not hear an appeal or revision; it is a proceeding quite independent of the original controversy; a decision in the exercise of this jurisdiction is a final decision
precedents.cited_holding: A petition to the High Court invoking this jurisdiction is a proceeding quite independent of the original controversy. The controversy in the High Court, in proceedings arising under Art. 226, ordinarily is whether a decision of, or a proceeding before, a Court or Tribunal or authority, should be allowed to stand or should be quashed

precedents.citation: Rambhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji and Others.  1

anchor.surface_text: Rambhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji and Others.  1  In that case, an appeal was brought to this Court against the judgment of an Election Tribunal, and one of the respondents wanted to support the order of the Tribunal on grounds which had been negatived by the Tribunal.

precedents.case_name: Rambhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji
precedents.cited_proposition: a respondent can support the judgment on grounds negatived by the tribunal or grounds not urged before the tribunal which might be apparent on the face of the record
precedents.cited_holding: while dealing with the appeal before it, this Court has the power to decide all the points arising from the judgment appealed against and even in the absence of an express provision like O. XLI, r. 22 of the Code of Civil Procedure, it can devise the appropriate procedure; considerations of justice require that this Court should permit a party to support the judgment even upon grounds which were negatived

precedents.citation: Powari Tea Estate v. Barkataki  M. K.  and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Powari Tea Estate v. Barkataki  M. K.  and Others 1 , this Court was examining the correctness of the decision reached by the Labour Court and, while doing so, it appeared- that the decision of Labour Court could be justified on a ground to which the Labour Court had not made any reference.

precedents.cited_proposition: the decision reached by the Labour Court can be justified on another ground to which the Labour Court has not referred, but which is patent on the record
precedents.cited_holding: But it appears from the record that the decision reached by the Labour Court can be justified on another ground to which the Labour Court has not referred, but which is patent on the record.

precedents.citation: Assam Oil Co. Ltd., New Delhi v. Its Workmen.  1

anchor.surface_text: Assam Oil Co. Ltd., New Delhi v. Its Workmen.  1  It appears to us that there might have been some force in this submission if the position had still remained as it was when the Tribunal made its direction for reinstatement.

precedents.case_name: Assam Oil Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: even if the Tribunal held that the order of removal was unjustified, the Tribunal should not have directed reinstatement because the employer had lost confidence in the employee

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; Tribunal's order setting aside removal of Kanraj Mehta upheld with liberty to Society to reinstitute enquiry; reinstatement direction not interfered with
directions: Society at liberty to institute fresh enquiry against Kanraj Mehta in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, it is clear that if the appellant wanted to challenge the correctness of the decision of the High Court holding that this dispute was an industrial dispute, the appropriate remedy was to come up in appeal against the judgment of the High Court either by a certificate under Art. 133 or by -special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The appellant having failed to do so, the, judgment of the High Court became final, and, consequently, binding between the parties.

Consequently, we consider that the order passed by the Tribunal was fully justified. The third and the last point urged by learned counsel for the appellant was that, even if the Tribunal held that the order of
